catalysts in dry reforming of methane for syngas production

div.h1:
Comparison of preparation methods for improving coke resistance of Ni-Ru/MgAl
2
O
4
catalysts in dry reforming of methane for syngas production

div.h2:
ABSTRACT
Formulae display:
?
Mathematical formulae have been encoded as MathML and are displayed in this HTML version using MathJax in order to improve their display. Uncheck the box to turn MathJax off. This feature requires Javascript. Click on a formula to zoom.

div.p:
A small loading of highly dispersed Ru on Ni/MgAl
2
O
4
catalyst was investigated in the dry reforming of methane (DRM) process. The catalysts were synthesized by impregnation and deposition-precipitation methods; the DRM reaction was performed at CH
4
/CO
2
/N
2
= 1/1/1 and 600‒750°C. The bimetallic Ni‒Ru catalysts exhibited improved reducibility and metal dispersion compared with that of the Ni catalyst. Among the synthesized catalysts, the Ru(D)/Ni(I)/MgAl
2
O
4
catalyst had the highest metal dispersion (7.23%) and largest amount of CO
2
desorption (135 μmol/g). Thus, this catalyst exhibited the highest CH
4
conversion (85.6%) at 750°C. Additionally, coke deposition of only 2.69% occurred during the stability test.
KEYWORDS:

With the recently increasing interest in climate change, interests in the development of environmental and sustainable technologies for reducing CO
2
, a major cause of global warming, are also increasing significantly. In this regard, dry reforming of methane (DRM) is an extremely sustainable technology for reducing CO
2
emissions because it uses CO
2
and CH
4
―the major greenhouse gases, as reactants (Parsapur, Chatterjee, and Huang
2020
).
(1)
C
H
4
+
C
O
2

2
H
2

2

O

298
K

+
247
k
J
/
m
o

(1)
(2)
C
O
2
+
H
2
→
H
2

+
C
O
Δ
H
298
K
=
+
41
k
J
/
m
o
l
(2)
(3)
C
H
4
+
H
2
O
→
3
H
2
+
C
O
Δ
H
298
K
=
+
228
k
J
/
m
o
l
(3)

The DRM reaction (
eq. 1)
is the process of producing synthesis gas (H
2
+ CO) using CH
4
and CO
2
(Edwards and Maitra
1995
). It is accompanied by the reverse water gas shift (RWGS) reaction (
eq. 2
), in which H
2
, formed as a product, reacts with CO
2
to produce steam and CO. Compared to oxygen or steam used in other CH
4
reforming processes, CO
2
used as an oxidizing agent in the DRM reaction is very stable. Consequently, the DRM reaction has endothermic nature, and proceeds mainly at a high temperature range of 650‒850°C (Abdullah, Abd Ghani, and Vo
2017
). Producing synthesized gas through DRM instead of steam methane reforming (SMR) (
eq. 3
), the CO
2
emission can be reduced by 0.5 Gt year
‒1
per 60 Mt year
‒1
of H
2
produced (Song et al.
2020
). The generated synthesis gas is a feed gas for the synthesis of chemical such as formaldehyde, oxo alcohols, and polycarbonates, which can be used in chemicals and fuels. Additionally, DRM has a lower H
2
/CO ratio than SMR, making it appropriate for obtaining hydrocarbons with long-chain via the Fischer-Tropsch (F‒T) synthesis (Hu and Ruckenstein
2002
). Furthermore, DRM is less expensive operating cost than SMR because DRM does not require complex gas separation from the final product (San-José-Alonso et al.
2009
).

Deactivation of catalyst takes place mainly owing to coke deposition and sintering in the DRM reaction. At high temperatures, sintering causes particle agglomeration due to the active metal migration, resulting in decrease of specific surface area and metal dispersion and increase of particle size. These factors lower the catalytic activity and affect other factors responsible for deactivation, such as coke deposition (Sehested
2006
). To suppress sintering, metal particles can be efficiently dispersed using a support to form strong metal-support interaction (SMSI), thereby preventing sintering (Park et al.
2015
).
(4)
C
O
+
H
2
→
H
2
O
+
C
(
Δ
H
298
K
=
−
131.3
k
J
/

o
l
)
(4)
(5)

O
2
+
2

2

2

2

(

k

)

(6)

(7)

(7)

The C‒H molar ratio for DRM is higher than that in other reforming processes, thus coke is deposited rapidly (Sehested
2006
). Coke deposition can occur due to CO hydrogenation (
eq. 4
), CO
2
hydrogenation (
eq. 5
), Boudouard reaction (
eq. 6
), and CH
4
decomposition (
eq. 7)
(Nikoo and Amin
2011
). In terms of thermodynamics, the endothermic CH
4
decomposition reaction proceeds actively at a high temperature of 650°C or higher. In contrast, CO disproportionation, CO
2
hydrogenation, and CO hydrogenation reactions have exothermic nature and therefore dominate at low temperatures (Zhang, Wang, and Dalai
2007
). In addition, coke deposition essentially occurs below 870°C under CH
4
/CO
2
ratio of 1, forming amorphous carbon, graphite, and filamentous carbon (Wang, Lu, and Millar
1996
). Among these, filamentous carbon has the maximum influence on the deactivation (Alipour, Rezaei, and Meshkani
2014
).

Various attempts have been made to prevent the deactivation of Ni catalysts from coke deposition. Typically, coke deposition is suppressed by adding a second metal species or selecting a suitable support. The addition of a second metal, such as Fe or Co, can effectively suppress coke deposition because the improved redox properties induced by Fe (Wang
2020b
) and the enhanced CO
2
dissociation provided by Co promoted the gasification of the coke deposits (Wu et al.
2019
). Moreover, the addition of small amounts of precious metals such as Ru, to Ni catalysts improves their catalytic activity and stability during the DRM reaction (Zhou et al.
2018
). In addition, by comparing the performances of NiO catalysts with various supports (SiO
2
, TiO
2
, Al
2
O
3
, hydrotalcite (Mg-Al), ZrO
2
, and MgO), we found that those supported on TiO
2
, Al
2
O
3
, and ZrO
2
exhibited significant amounts of coke deposition. On the other hand, the NiO/Mg-Al catalyst exhibited the lowest amount of coke deposition due to the high basicity of the Mg-Al support (Zhang et al.
2015
). Because Mg-Al has a higher basicity than the Al
2
O
3
support, catalysts possessing the former show superior CO
2
adsorption. Consequently, oxygen produced by subsequent CO
2
dissociation promotes the gasification of the coke, thus suppressing coke deposition (Kumari and Sengupta
2020
). In addition, the layered double hydroxide (LDH) of Mg-Al affects the metal dispersion and thermal stability of the active metal through strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) (Wang et al.
2020a
). For this reason, Mg-Al was selected as the support for the present catalyst preparation.

To improve the properties of Ni catalysts, a small amount of Ru (0.5 wt%) was doped into a 7 wt% Ni/MgO-Al
2
O
3
catalyst to obtain a highly dispersed catalytic system. The effect of the Ni and Ru preparation method was conducted. In addition, the effects of the doping order were examined by loading of Ni and Ru either sequentially or simultaneously. The optimal method for preparing a highly active and durable Ni‒Ru/MgAl
2
O
4
catalyst was determined by evaluating the coke resistance and catalytic activity in DRM reaction.

Ru(NO)(NO
3
)
x
∙(OH)
y
(1.5%), Ni(NO
3
)
2
∙6H
2
O (97%) were provided by Sigma-Aldrich and JUNSEI, respectively. MgO-Al
2
O
3
mixed oxide (MG30) was purchased from SASOL. KOH (85%) and urea (60.06%) were provided by JUNSEI as precipitant. The Ni–Ru/MgAl
2
O
4
catalysts were synthesized by deposition-precipitation (D) method and impregnation (I) method via incipient wetness. The Ru(I)/Ni(I)/MgAl
2
O
4
catalyst was impregnated Ni and Ru, sequentially. By deposition-precipitation method, the Ru‒Ni(D)/MgAl
2
O
4
catalyst was synthesized, 10 wt% KOH aqua solution was injected drop-wise as a precipitation agent to titrate at 80°C until a pH of 11.5 was attained and aged for 1 day. The temperature of the solution was maintained using a heating mantle set to 80°C. Next, the catalysts were washed with distilled water. The Ni impregnation was preferentially performed in case of the Ru(D)/Ni(I)/MgAl
2
O
4
catalyst. Ru was added by deposition-precipitation method, in which 5.7 wt% urea aqua solution was added as precipitation agent to 1:200 Ru:urea mixture and aged at 80°C for 8 hr and at 25°C for 12 hr. This was followed by filtration and washing. All synthesized catalysts were dried at 80°C for 6 hr, and the calcination temperature was 800°C for 6 hr. Ru(D)/MgAl
2
O
4
and Ni(D)/MgAl
2
O
4
were used as reference catalysts.

A schematic image of the reactor applied to evaluate the reaction activity of the catalyst is shown in
Figure 1
. To investigate the catalytic activity in the DRM reaction, a mixture of the catalyst (50 mg, 150‒250 μm) diluted with MgAl
2
O
4
(500 mg, 150‒250 μm) with a 1:10 ratio was packed in a fixed bed reactor system using a 3/8” quartz reactor. Before the catalytic DRM reaction, the temperature of catalyst was maintained at 700°C for 2 hr with 10% H
2
mixture (balanced N
2
) for reduction. The reactant was then added at CH
4
/CO
2
/N
2
= 1/1/1 and the GHSV was 144,000 ml·h
‒1
·g
cat
‒1
at atmospheric pressure. In the reaction temperature range of 600‒750°C, reactions were performed by gradually decreasing the temperature from 750°C in 50°C increments. The K-type thermocouple (TC) was placed inside the catalyst layer to determine and control the temperature of catalyst bed. To examine the stability and anti-coking properties of the catalyst, the catalyst (50 mg) was held without diluent, and the reaction was carried out at 600°C for 20 hr with CH
4
/CO
2
/N
2
= 1/1/1 and a GHSV of 144,000 ml·h
‒1
·g
cat
‒1
. The gas product was measured using a micro-gas chromatograph equipped with a TCD (3000A Micro GC, Agilent). The micro GC was calibrated by reference gas including the product gas composition. The standard error of the mean was within the error range of ± 0.4%.

div.span:
Comparison of preparation methods for improving coke resistance of Ni-Ru/MgAl
2
O
4
catalysts in dry reforming of methane for syngas production

div.div:
Dahye
Song
,
Unho
Jung
,
Hyo Been
Im
,
Tae Ho
Lee
,
Young-Eun
Kim
,
Ki Bong
Lee
&
Kee Young
Koo

div.p:
Figure 1.
Schematic of fixed bed reactor for DRM reaction

Figure 1.
Schematic of fixed bed reactor for DRM reaction

The physical and chemical properties of the Ni‒Ru catalysts are exhibited in
Table 1
. The ICP analysis exhibited that the metal loading amount of supported Ni and Ru were 7% and 0.5%, respectively. The Ni catalyst had a specific surface area of 123.37 m
2
·
g
‒1
and the addition of Ru to the Ni catalyst reduced the specific surface area slightly owing to pore blocking of the support by the metal. The specific surface area was also influenced by the preparation method of the Ru metal. The specific surface area of the Ru(I)/Ni(I)/MgAl
2
O
4
catalyst, which was prepared by doping the Ni(I)/MgAl
2
O
4
catalyst with Ru using the impregnation method (I), was 114.34 m
2
·g
‒1
, whereas the specific surface area of the Ru(D)/Ni(I)/MgAl
2
O
4
catalyst synthesized by the deposition-precipitation method (D) was 147.71 m
2
·g
‒1
, which was higher than that of other Ni‒Ru catalysts. This was because of the formation of small-sized and highly dispersed metal particles, which could be attributed to the deposition-precipitation preparation method. Chemisorption analysis was performed to confirm that a small amount of Ru was highly dispersed on Ni metals. Among the prepared catalysts, the Ru(D)/MgAl
2
O
4
catalyst supporting only Ru showed the highest metal dispersion (33.19%), while the Ni(D)/MgAl
2
O
4
catalyst had the lowest metal dispersion (5.53%). Among the bimetallic catalysts loaded with Ni and Ru, the metal dispersion decreased in the order of Ru(D)/Ni(I)/MgAl
2
O
4
> Ru‒Ni(D)/MgAl
2
O
4
> Ru(I)/Ni(I)/MgAl
2
O
4
. Therefore, from the BET and chemisorption results, it was determined that the deposition-precipitation method is advantageous compared to the impregnation method for supporting a small loading of highly dispersed Ru metal on the surface of catalyst.

div.span:
Comparison of preparation methods for improving coke resistance of Ni-Ru/MgAl
2
O
4
catalysts in dry reforming of methane for syngas production

div.div:
Dahye
Song
,
Unho
Jung
,
Hyo Been
Im
,
Tae Ho
Lee
,
Young-Eun
Kim
,
Ki Bong
Lee
&
Kee Young
Koo

h3.p:
Table 1.
Characteristics of Ni-Ru catalysts with various preparation method

div.p:
H
2
-TPR analysis was carried out to evaluate the reduction characteristics of Ni, Ru, and Ru‒promoted Ni/MgAl
2
O
4
catalysts (
Figure 2
(a)). The Ru catalyst exhibits a peak at a relatively low temperature (441°C), and the Ni catalyst exhibits a peak at a high temperature (600°C or higher). For the bimetallic Ni‒Ru catalysts, the reduction temperature was affected by the Ru doping method. In previous work, noble metals such as Ru and Rh have been reported that promote the reduction of Ni catalysts (Tengfei et al.
2015
) and in this study, all Ni‒Ru catalysts showed improved reduction characteristics. Furthermore, they showed a reduction peak at lower temperatures than Ni‒based catalysts, which can be attributed to the H
2
spillover effect of Ru (Lucci et al.
2015
). This is consistent with the increase in H
2
consumption shown in
Table 1
. Therefore, the addition of Ru promotes the reduction of NiO to metallic Ni; thus, affecting the activity of the catalyst.

div.span:
Comparison of preparation methods for improving coke resistance of Ni-Ru/MgAl
2
O
4
catalysts in dry reforming of methane for syngas production

div.div:
Dahye
Song
,
Unho
Jung
,
Hyo Been
Im
,
Tae Ho
Lee
,
Young-Eun
Kim
,
Ki Bong
Lee
&
Kee Young
Koo

div.p:
Figure 2.
(a) H
2
-TPR profiles and (b) CO
2
-TPD profiles of Ni‒Ru catalysts via preparation method

Figure 2.
(a) H
2
-TPR profiles and (b) CO
2
-TPD profiles of Ni‒Ru catalysts via preparation method

CO
2
-TPD analysis results were accomplished to evaluate the basic properties of the sample surface (
Figure 2
(b)). CO
2
adsorption on the surface of the active metals (Ni, Ni-Ru) is promoted by adding an alkaline metal (e.g., Mg, Ca, or K); this is because CO
2
is an acidic gas that tends to adsorb on basic sites (Azzouz,
2006
). All catalysts showed TPD peaks over the temperature range 100‒400°C. Because the oxygen affinity was enhanced by the addition of Ru, the amount of adsorbed CO
2
increased for the Ni-Ru catalysts, compared with the Ni(D)/MgAl
2
O
4
catalyst (Zhou et al.
2018
). The Ru(D)/Ni(I)/MgAl
2
O
4
catalyst adsorbed more CO
2
than the Ru‒based catalysts prepared by the different methods. These observations are promising, as increasing the amount of CO
2
adsorption can have an advantage on coke deposition and CO
2
conversion, as CO
2
reduces coke deposition by gasification of hydrocarbon on the surface of the catalyst (Bobadilla et al.
2018
).

In DRM reaction, the catalytic activity was evaluated at the range of 600‒750°C.
Figure 3
displays the conversions of CH
4
and CO
2
. The CH
4
and CO
2
conversion exhibited higher values with rising the temperature of catalyst bed. The Ru(D)/MgAl
2
O
4
catalyst exhibited higher activity of the catalyst than the Ni(D)/MgAl
2
O
4
catalyst, although only 0.5 wt% Ru was supported on the MgAl
2
O
4
. Contrastingly, the Ni‒Ru bimetallic catalysts exhibited improved conversion compared with the monometallic catalysts. Particularly, the Ru(D)/Ni(I)/MgAl
2
O
4
and Ru‒Ni(D)/MgAl
2
O
4
catalysts synthesized by the deposition-precipitation method exhibited a better conversion compared with the Ru(I)/Ni(I)/MgAl
2
O
4
catalysts synthesized by the impregnation method. This indicates that the catalytic activity is improved by supporting a small loading of abundantly dispersed Ru on the Ni catalyst by the deposition-precipitation method. Additionally, in a Ni monometallic catalyst, as reaction temperature decreased, the difference increased the conversion with the Ni‒Ru catalyst synthesized by the deposition-precipitation method. The highest feed conversion was gained for the Ru(D)/Ni(I)/MgAl
2
O
4
catalyst, and it was attributed to the high metal dispersion and reducibility, which are a result of the synthesis method, viz. impregnation and deposition-precipitation of Ni and Ru, respectively. The catalytic activities of the Ni-Ru catalysts were compared to those of catalysts from previous studies that employed MgO-Al
2
O
3
supports (Table S1). At the same temperature (750°C), our Ru(D)/Ni(I)/MgAl
2
O
4
catalyst showed a lower space velocity than that of catalyst reported by Fang et al. (Fang et al.
2018
), but its feed conversion was superior. Specifically, the previously reported catalyst had a CH
4
and CO
2
conversions of 70% and 72%, respectively, while those of our catalyst were 86% and 92%, respectively. In addition, at a lower reaction temperature of 650°C, the Ru(D)/Ni(I) catalyst exhibited higher CH
4
(59%) and CO
2
(70%) conversion than those (30% and 40%, respectively) of a previously reported 15% Ni-0.5% Ru catalyst (Bobadilla et al.
2018
). According to the DRM reaction equation (
eq. 1
), the H
2
/CO ratio of 1 is expected; however, based on the experiments, the H
2
/CO ratio at 750°C was approximately 0.7‒0.8 (
Table 1
) owing to the RWGS reaction, which is a side reaction.

div.span:
Comparison of preparation methods for improving coke resistance of Ni-Ru/MgAl
2
O
4
catalysts in dry reforming of methane for syngas production

div.div:
Dahye
Song
,
Unho
Jung
,
Hyo Been
Im
,
Tae Ho
Lee
,
Young-Eun
Kim
,
Ki Bong
Lee
&
Kee Young
Koo

div.p:
Figure 3.
CH
4
conversion and CO
2
conversion with reaction temperature over Ni‒Ru catalysts prepared by different methods (reaction conditions: CH
4
/CO
2
/N
2
= 1/1/1, GHSV = 144,000 ml·h
−1
·g
cat
−1
, T = 600‒750°C)

Figure 3.
CH
4
conversion and CO
2
conversion with reaction temperature over Ni‒Ru catalysts prepared by different methods (reaction conditions: CH
4
/CO
2
/N
2
= 1/1/1, GHSV = 144,000 ml·h
−1
·g
cat
−1
, T = 600‒750°C)

To compare the durability of the catalyst, a stability test of the prepared catalysts was carried out by holding only the catalyst without diluent at 600°C for 20 h. The conversions of CH
4
and CO
2
and H
2
/CO ratios are exhibited in
Figure 4
and
Table 2
, respectively. The Ni monometallic catalyst presented a 3.8% reduction in the CH
4
conversion and the CO
2
conversion reduced by 2.7% during the 20 hr reaction. On the other hand, in the Ru monometallic catalyst, the conversion of CH
4
decreased by 1.8% and the conversion of CO
2
decreased by 2.3%. Furthermore, the Ru(I)/Ni(I)/MgAl
2
O
4
catalyst synthesized by the impregnation method exhibited a difference in CH
4
conversion of 2.9%, and the CO
2
conversion decreased by 3.4%, while the CH
4
conversion of the Ru‒Ni(D)/MgAl
2
O
4
and Ru(D)/Ni(I)/MgAl
2
O
4
catalysts synthesized by the deposition-precipitation method showed a 2% conversion difference and the CO
2
conversion decreased by 2.6% for the DRM reaction. Therefore, the Ni‒Ru bimetallic catalysts showed higher stability than the Ni monometallic catalyst.

Comparison of preparation methods for improving coke resistance of Ni-Ru/MgAl

O

catalysts in dry reforming of methane for syngas production

div.p:
Figure 4.
CH
4
conversion and CO
2
conversion over Ni‒Ru catalysts with time on stream (TOS) (reaction conditions: CH
4
/CO
2
/N
2
= 1/1/1, GHSV = 144,000 ml·h
−1
·g
cat
−1
, T = 600°C, TOS = 20 h)

Figure 4.
CH
4
conversion and CO
2
conversion over Ni‒Ru catalysts with time on stream (TOS) (reaction conditions: CH
4
/CO
2
/N
2
= 1/1/1, GHSV = 144,000 ml·h
−1
·g
cat
−1
, T = 600°C, TOS = 20 h)

In the stability test, the difference in performance of the catalyst synthesized by the impregnation and deposition-precipitation method was revealed in the H
2
/CO ratio. The H
2
/CO ratios of the Ni monometallic catalyst and Ru monometallic catalyst are 0.36 and 0.39, respectively. Ru(I)/Ni(I)/MgAl
2
O
4
catalyst synthesized by the impregnation method presented a H
2
/CO ratio of 0.41, whereas the Ru‒Ni(D)/MgAl
2
O
4
and Ru(D)/Ni(I)/MgAl
2
O
4
catalysts prepared by the deposition-precipitation method showed H
2
/CO ratios of 0.44 and 0.52, respectively. The highest H
2
/CO ratio was obtained by the Ru(D)/Ni(I)/MgAl
2
O
4
catalyst, and the CH
4
and CO
2
conversions were proportional to the H
2
/CO ratio.

The shape of the coke formed on the catalyst surface was observed using SEM analysis. The SEM image in
Figure 5
confirmed that filamentous carbon was formed on the surface of the catalyst after the stability test. Filamentous carbon forms at temperatures above 450°C and deactivates the catalyst by inducing pore plugging on the catalyst surface (Ginsburg et al.
2005
). Therefore, a high temperature of 680°C or higher is required for coke oxidation (Alipour, Rezaei, and Meshkani
2014
). A significant amount of filamentous carbon was deposited on the surface of the Ni(D)/MgAl
2
O
4
catalyst, whereas the Ru(D)/MgAl
2
O
4
catalyst had less coke than the Ni catalyst. By adding Ru to the Ni-Ru catalyst, the amount of carbon formed is reduced compared with that of the Ni catalyst. A somewhat larger amount of coke was generated in the Ru(I)/Ni(I)/MgAl
2
O
4
and Ru‒Ni(D)/MgAl
2
O
4
catalyst than Ru(D)/Ni(I)/MgAl
2
O
4
catalyst among the Ni‒Ru catalysts.

div.span:
Comparison of preparation methods for improving coke resistance of Ni-Ru/MgAl
2
O
4
catalysts in dry reforming of methane for syngas production

div.div:
Dahye
Song
,
Unho
Jung
,
Hyo Been
Im
,
Tae Ho
Lee
,
Young-Eun
Kim
,
Ki Bong
Lee
&
Kee Young
Koo

div.p:
Figure 5.
SEM images (top) of spent catalysts (a) Ni(D)/MgAl
2
O
4
, (b) Ru(D)/MgAl
2
O
4
, (c) Ru(I)/Ni(I)/MgAl
2
O
4
, (d) Ru(D)/Ni(I)/MgAl
2
O
4
and TG profiles (bottom) of spent catalysts under air (reaction condition: CH
4
/CO
2
/N
2
= 1/1/1, GHSV = 144,000 ml·h
−1
·g
cat
−1
, T = 600°C, TOS = 20 h)

Figure 5.
SEM images (top) of spent catalysts (a) Ni(D)/MgAl
2
O
4
, (b) Ru(D)/MgAl
2
O
4
, (c) Ru(I)/Ni(I)/MgAl
2
O
4
, (d) Ru(D)/Ni(I)/MgAl
2
O
4
and TG profiles (bottom) of spent catalysts under air (reaction condition: CH
4
/CO
2
/N
2
= 1/1/1, GHSV = 144,000 ml·h
−1
·g
cat
−1
, T = 600°C, TOS = 20 h)

TGA was used to determine the amount of coke produced in the catalyst after the reaction (
Figure 5
,
Table 2
). In the TGA procedure, H
2
O and CO
2
are removed below 200°C and oxidation due to amorphous carbon occurs in the range 250‒300°C, while filamentous carbon is oxidized at approximately 600°C (Alipour, Rezaei, and Meshkani
2014
; Guo et al.
2004
; Zhang, Wang, and Dalai
2007
). As a result, upon comparing the weight losses of the Ru-containing catalysts (Ru(D), Ru(I)/Ni(I), Ru(D)/Ni(I), and Ru-Ni(D)) in accordance with temperature, we observed no remarkable weight loss for any of the samples. However, a significant amount of coke deposition occurred on the Ni(D) catalyst (65.9%). In particular, weight loss was mainly observed at approximately 600°C. As filamentous coke oxidizes at temperatures above 600°C, and it was observed in the SEM analyses, filamentous coke was confirmed to form predominantly from during the DRM reaction. The largest amount of coke formation occurred at 65.93 wt% in the Ni(D)/MgAl
2
O
4
monometallic catalyst. On the other hand, in the Ru(D)/MgAl
2
O
4
monometallic catalyst, coke formation only occurred at 2.92 wt%. Similar to the SEM analysis, TGA confirmed that the amount of coke decreased in the Ru-promoted Ni catalysts. The Ru-Ni(D)/MgAl
2
O
4
catalyst only formed 10.66 wt% coke, and the Ru(D)/Ni(I)/MgAl
2
O
4
and Ru(I)/Ni(I)/MgAl
2
O
4
catalysts formed 2.69 and 3.86 wt% coke, respectively. This indicates that less coke formation occurred for bimetallic Ni‒Ru catalysts than for the Ni(D)/MgAl
2
O
4
catalyst. Therefore, the high oxygen affinity of highly dispersed Ru in Ru-promoted Ni catalysts can enhance the coke resistance of the catalyst.

In this study, a bimetallic catalyst in which a small loading of highly dispersed Ru was supported on a Ni catalyst by the deposition-precipitation method showed high CH
4
and CO
2
conversion in the DRM reaction and effectively suppressed coke deposition. Therefore, the Ni‒Ru catalyst exhibited improved metal dispersion and reducing properties owing to the spillover effect of Ru, thereby increasing the catalytic activity and coking resistance compared with the Ni monometallic catalyst. In addition, the deposition-precipitation method was advantageous for doping with a small loading of highly dispersed Ru precious metal, as evidenced by the higher metal dispersion and specific surface area than those of the impregnation method. Particularly, the Ru(D)/Ni(I)/MgAl
2
O
4
catalyst, which was synthesized by impregnation with Ni and the deposition-precipitation of Ru, had the highest metal dispersion (7.23%) and largest amount of CO
2
desorption (135 μmol/g) among the prepared catalysts. The exposed active sites on its surface increased due to the high metal dispersion, and the coke on the catalysts surface was oxidized via oxygen produced by the dissociation of CO
2
adsorbed on the catalyst. Therefore, it indicated the highest CH
4
and CO
2
conversion in addition to excellent anti-coking properties in the DRM reaction. Hence, the addition of a small loading of highly dispersed Ru supported on a Ni catalyst improved the activity of catalyst and coking resistance of the bimetallic catalyst in the DRM reaction. In the future, we intend to compare the performances of Ru(D)/Ni(D) catalysts sequentially prepared by the deposition-precipitation method. Long-term stability tests of these catalysts will also be performed.

Table 1.
Characteristics of Ni-Ru catalysts with various preparation method

a
Estimated from N
2
adsorption at – 196°C

b
Estimated from CO-chemisorption at 50°C

c
Estimated from the integration of H
2
-TPR peaks

d
Estimated from the integration of CO
2
-TPD peaks

e
H
2
/CO ratio over prepared catalysts at 750°C.

Table 2.
Activity and amount of carbon deposited catalysts over prepared catalysts at 600°C

No potential conflict of interest was reported by the author(s).

Supplemental data for this article can be accessed on the
publisher’s website
.
